title: Avoiding pharma dependence on China
summary: The article argues that European health systems' low drug prices are driving drug discovery to the US and China, while libertarians and classical liberals have proposed solutions like higher European prices and easier US factory construction.

title: Betting markets in everything
summary: The article discusses the comment section with the fields email, author, website, and comment, as well as options to receive notifications for follow-up comments and new posts via email.

title: Wednesday assorted links
summary: This article provides a form for users to submit comments, including fields for email, author, website, and the comment itself, with options to receive notifications for follow-up comments and new posts.

title: This is Vindication???
summary: The article critiques Joe Nocera's argument that protectionist views have been vindicated, presenting counter-evidence such as economic data and the revitalization of a previously struggling city, while also noting the lack of data supporting Nocera's claims.

title: My excellent Conversation with Jack Clark
summary: Jack Clark and Tyler Cowen discuss the potential economic impacts of artificial general intelligence, focusing on areas like economic growth rates, the challenges of integrating AI into the physical world, and the cautious outlook on AI-driven economic expansion.

title: China missing facts of the day
summary: China has stopped publishing hundreds of data points on its economy, including land sales, foreign investment, and unemployment indicators, without providing reasons, coinciding with economic struggles and efforts to control the narrative.

title: UK estimate of the day
summary: A leading psychologist suggests that a majority of Britons may now identify as neurodivergent due to reduced stigma and increased self-diagnosis.

title: Are recent cohorts in worse health?
summary: The study of individuals aged 51-54 reveals an increase in limitations, especially pain and cognitive impairment, in younger cohorts, but overall health among those aged 62-64 remains high, with significant work capacity challenges for those without high school degrees.

title: Tuesday assorted links
summary: The article discusses using LLMs for economics papers, beautiful words, macroeconomics of tariffs, China's One Child Policy, colorblindness, empathy, and long-living organisms.

title: Has Clothing Declined in Quality?
summary: The article argues that while some perceive a decline in clothing quality due to fast fashion and international trade, this is a consumer-driven shift towards fashionable clothing and not a true decline, with functional and high-quality options still available alongside the rise of cheaper, trend-focused items.

title: Guatemala vs. El Salvador
summary: Guatemala generally has a slightly better economy than El Salvador, with higher GDP per capita and a stronger GDP growth rate, and a more robust democracy, making it the relative economic success story in Central America.

title: Whoâ€™s next?
summary: The United Arab Emirates is introducing artificial intelligence into its public school curriculum for all grades in the 2025-2026 academic year to become a regional leader in AI development.

title: Latin America is swinging to the traditional, non-Trumpian right
summary: Latin America's preference for leaders with free market and open economy agendas, unlike the Western trend towards the far right, may help the region overcome its economic slump and attract capital.

title: Lady Liberty of the Pacific
summary: The author suggests building a statue called "Lady Liberty of the Pacific" instead of reopening Alcatraz as a super-max prison, symbolizing American progress and Bay Area technology.

title: Tabarrok on the Movie Tariff
summary: The article discusses the confusion and potential negative impacts within the film industry regarding Donald Trump's proposed movie tariffs, citing uncertainties about their implementation and the potential for widespread harm to both U.S. and international entities.
